awd_titl_txt: Developing the Next Generation of STEM Leaders: 2019 TCUP Leaders' Forum and Professional Development for NSF-TCUP Eligible Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
The mission of the NSF Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to support the strengthening of STEM education and research capacity at Native-serving institutions. The project titled "Developing the Next Generation of STEM Leaders: 2019 TCUP Leaders' Forum and Professional Development for NSF-TCUP Eligible Institutions" aligns well with this mission. Administered by Sisseton Wahpeton Community College, project personnel organize, design and deliver two types of professional development events for TCU personnel interested in developing their leadership, grant-related skills, and STEM programs. The first event, the Tribal Leaders' Forum (TLF), provides a venue for TCU personnel to participate in formal sessions in which they explore best practices and innovative approaches to STEM research, instruction and evaluation. The second event is a three-day technical assistance workshop offered to TCU personnel that addresses proposal preparation and project management. Follow up technical assistance is offered as well.

The goals of the TLF are to strengthen STEM leadership skills in TCUP personnel, to promote STEM education and research at TCUs, to strengthen and expand partnerships between TCUs and mainstream institutions, and to develop strategies for enhancing workforce potential in tribal communities. The goals of the TA workshops are to provide targeted support to TCUs in preparing proposals to secure NSF funding and to develop skills in administering grant projects. A book reporting on the project events will disseminate findings from the work to TCU personnel and other interested stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Developing the Next Generation of STEM Leaders: 2019 TCUP Leaders' Forum and Professional Development for NSF-TCUP Eligible Institutions project was designed to allow the participants to their share experiences and discuss strategies that will improve their projects and collaborate with their peers. The primary activities were to host a Leaders’ Forum for PIs with an existing NSF TCUP award and a subsequent Proposal Writing & Grant Management workshop for prospective eligible institutions and new PIs. These were originally scheduled for the spring and summer of 2020; however, these events were postponed due to the pandemic.

During the pandemic, the project hosted a number of webinars to provide professional development and to facilitate communication within the TCUP community. While these events achieved a number of the project’s objectives, these virtual events did not fully achieve the purpose of the project. As a result an in-person Leaders’ Forum was held in September of 2022, as originally intended. This was followed by the Proposal Writing & Grant Management workshop in February of 2023. Both events were conducted in Minneapolis Minnesota. A second Leaders’ Forum was hosted by the project in November of 2023.

The project addressed challenges and identified potential solutions for building research and education capacity at TCUP-eligible institutions that serve some of the country’s most under-represented groups, often in very rural  and economic depressed location. Key aspects of the project included strategic planning and best practices to develop collaboration between institutions, provide professional development opportunities to current and perspective PIs and other institutional leaders, promote communication with peers from other TCUP institutions and the NSF program officers, and increase awareness of new opportunities in STEM education and research.

Results are expected to have broad impacts beyond the confines of science, engineering, and academics world impacting educational pathways and opportunities for Native American, Alaskan Native, and Native Hawaiian students. Based on anecdotal and self-reported accounts these events encouraged the development of new proposals, including collaborative projects, and increased the confidence of new PIs to manage their awards. Additional information is publicly available on the Native Science Report (https://nativesciencereport.org/) website.

 


Last Modified: 11/09/2024
Modified by: Scott Morgan
